title: Add Explanations for Why References Are Included in Copilot Responses
body: Type: Feature Request When GitHub Copilot answers questions, it lists the number of references used and what they are. However, it would be helpful to include explanatory text for each reference explaining why it was introduced or how it relates to the response. VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.104.0-insider (7be2a0b2e60c47a0dbd586fc56b64b55e03bd954, 2025-09-04T20:16:36.013Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: vscode copilot agent doesn't wait for build to finish
body:
Type: Bug the terminal integration with the agent seems very broken and unreliable. the agent kicks of a build (either as a task or as terminal command) and either 1) declares right away that the build finished and passed, or 2) waits a bit, doesn't realize it's still going and tries to rerun the build again. very bad experience. title: fix supporting changed github info property
With NVDA, VSCode now spuriously jumps the cursor to the top of the file on some operations

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make an empty file.
2. Put a few lines in it.
3. Arrow down to a line that's not the first.
4. Hit ctrl+g
5. Hit escape
6. You're now at the top of the file!

For the curious I use go to line and cancellation to get the line number--ctrl+g escape seems to be the fastest way to do it.  That's the easiest way to repro but not the only place this happens.

Formatting a file triggers the problem like at least 90% of the time.  Editing code out from under VSCode isn't something I can easily repro with but seems to do it sometimes.  That is to say that while I'm using go to line for the repro it's happening in more than just that spot.  For lack of better phrasing my position used to be relatively "sticky" and has been for years, now it's not.  The old behavior was super super useful given how hard it can be to relocate one's place as a screen reader user.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider
- OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a project with the following debug configuration in `launch.json`
```json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program",
            "skipFiles": [
                "<node_internals>/**"
            ],
            "runtimeExecutable": "node",
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "test.js"
            ],
        },
    ]
}
```
2. Create a `test.js` file with any code that won't exit immediately or just add a breakpoint.
3. Start debugging
4. Click the "Stop/Disconnect" button in the debug toolbar

The running program and debug session do not stop and eventually VSCode crashes. Additionally while VSCode is still running editor info panels on hover just show "loading...".

title: telemetry for accept input suggestions is wrong for foreground terminals, we do not await command finished from output monitor

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body: Unlike bg terminals, fg terminals do not await `onCommandFinished` from `outputMonitor`. Their `strategy.execution` call finishes before the properties have been updated, so are all 0. It finishes because it becomes idle for a second https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/7be2a0b2e60c47a0dbd586fc56b64b55e03bd954/src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/browser/executeStrategy/richExecuteStrategy.ts#L55-L59 We'd need to create the output monitor in the strategy once the start marker has been created and then await `outputMonitor.onCommandFinished` in the `onDone` function to fix this. Doing so would also fix cases where the fg terminal has a bg process and it hangs. cc @Tyriar

title: Fix TypeError messages in Position class Min/Max methods
body:
The `Position.Min()` and `Position.Max()` static methods were throwing bare `TypeError()` exceptions without descriptive error messages when called with no arguments. This made debugging difficult as developers couldn't understand what went wrong.

**Before:**
```typescript
static Min(...positions: Position[]): Position {
    if (positions.length === 0) {
        throw new TypeError();  // No helpful message
    }
    // ...
}
```

**After:**
```typescript
static Min(...positions: Position[]): Position {
    if (positions.length === 0) {
        throw new TypeError('Expected at least one position');  // Clear error message
    }
    // ...
}
```

This change improves the developer experience by providing clear, actionable error messages when these methods are misused. The fix applies to both `Position.Min()` and `Position.Max()` methods in the VS Code API.

**Impact:**
- Better debugging experience for extension developers
- No breaking changes to existing functionality
- Consistent with other error handling patterns in the codebase

**Testing:**
- Verified that the error messages are properly displayed
- Confirmed no other instances of similar issues exist in the codebase
- Validated TypeScript compilation still works correctly

Type: Bug Issue is intermittent. Don't have a repro. I've been working with the Claude 4 model in AI chat. Interactions work fine and then after submitting a prompt I received: Sorry, your request failed. Please try again. Request id: 1cec7859-72ac-4c9b-b8ca-ffda7f0c448c Reason: Request Failed: 400 {"error":{"message":"tools.13.custom.input_schema: Field required","code":"invalid_request_body"}} Since then I submit a prompt and the text disappears (isn't shown in the chat history section) and no response occurs. I"ve treied switcing models, restarted VS code and the problem is persisting. What is interesting (this has been going on for a few hours of outage) is that when I close VS code and restart I see the LL responded. title: Add Developer: Diagnose Policy Configuration command with comprehensive policy service analysis
body:
This PR implements a new developer command that provides comprehensive diagnostics for policy configuration and authentication state in VS Code, with detailed analysis of individual policy services and their sources.

## What this adds

**New Developer Command**: `Developer: Diagnose Policy Configuration`
- Accessible via F1 command palette
- Categorized under Developer commands for easy discovery

## Key Features

### Comprehensive Policy Analysis
- **Individual Policy Service Breakdown**: Shows policies from specific services (Account Policy, Native Policy, Configuration Policy)
- **Policy Configuration Registry**: Includes detailed policy configuration data from the configuration registry
- **Enhanced Source Attribution**: Distinguishes between different policy service types rather than generic "Policy" source
- **Complete Policy Inventory**: Collects all policy settings with their definitions, values, and metadata
- **Policy-to-Configuration Mapping**: Shows how policy names map to configuration keys

### Authentication Analysis  
- **Provider Enumeration**: Lists all registered authentication providers
- **Account Discovery**: Collects signed-in accounts across all providers (GitHub, Microsoft, etc.)
- **Scope Reporting**: Shows granted scopes for each authenticated session
- **Sync Account Integration**: Includes user data sync account information
- **Security-First Design**: Only reports token metadata (presence, length) without exposing actual token values

### Enhanced Diagnostic Output
- **Structured JSON**: Opens results in a new editor tab with JSON syntax highlighting
- **Dual Policy Views**: Both individual policy service data and policy configuration registry data
- **Rich Metadata**: Includes policy names, types, scopes, configuration properties, and source attribution
- **Error Handling**: Gracefully handles provider errors while continuing analysis
- **Performance Tracking**: Reports collection time via telemetry

## Implementation Details

### Architecture
- **Service Integration**: Uses dependency injection for IConfigurationService, IPolicyService, IAuthenticationService, IUserDataSyncAccountService, and configuration registry
- **Policy Service Analysis**: Leverages configuration registry to provide detailed policy service information
- **Error Resilience**: Comprehensive error handling with detailed logging
- **VS Code Patterns**: Follows established contribution patterns using Action2 registration

### Security & Privacy
- **Token Safety**: Never exposes actual authentication tokens
- **GDPR Compliance**: Telemetry follows proper classification patterns with appropriate purposes
- **Audit Trail**: Full logging for troubleshooting and analysis

## Example Output

The command generates a comprehensive JSON report with enhanced policy service information:

```json
{
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:00.000Z",
  "policies": [
    {
      "name": "workbench.settings.enableNaturalLanguageSearch",
      "definition": { "type": "boolean" },
      "policyValue": true,
      "configurationValue": false,
      "source": "Configuration Policy",
      "policyName": "EnableNaturalLanguageSearch",
      "policyType": "boolean",
      "configurationKey": "workbench.settings.enableNaturalLanguageSearch",
      "hasConfigurationProperty": true,
      "configurationScope": 1
    }
  ],
  "policyConfigurations": [
    {
      "policyName": "EnableNaturalLanguageSearch",
      "configurationKey": "workbench.settings.enableNaturalLanguageSearch",
      "policyValue": true,
      "configurationValue": false,
      "hasPolicy": true,
      "source": "Configuration Policy"
    }
  ],
  "accounts": [
    {
      "providerId": "github",
      "accountId": "user123",
      "accountLabel": "username@github.com",
      "scopes": ["read:user", "repo"],
      "hasToken": true,
      "tokenLength": 40
    }
  ],
  "summary": {
    "totalPolicies": 15,
    "activePolicies": 8,
    "totalPolicyConfigurations": 12,
    "activePolicyConfigurations": 6,
    "totalAccounts": 3,
    "authProviders": 2
  }
}
```

## Use Cases

This enhanced diagnostic is particularly valuable for:
- **Enterprise Administrators**: Understanding which specific policy service is enforcing each setting
- **Support Engineers**: Diagnosing policy source conflicts and configuration issues
- **Security Audits**: Reviewing policy service types and their active configurations
- **Development Teams**: Troubleshooting policy-related behaviors with detailed service attribution

The implementation provides comprehensive analysis of all policy services (AccountPolicyService, NativePolicyService, PolicyConfiguration) as requested in the feedback, with detailed source attribution and configuration registry integration.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

Created from VS Code via the [GitHub Pull Request](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github) extension.

title: Support Mult-WAN network interfaces
body:
Type: Bug ``` Nous n’avons pas pu traiter votre requête. Veuillez réessayer. ID de requête : 0dba228f-f33d-4efe-80ff-4db4ea889a5e Raison : Please check your firewall rules and network connection then try again. Error Code: net::ERR_NETWORK_CHANGED. ``` Which roughly translates to: > We were unable to process your request. Please try again. Request ID: 0dba228f-f33d-4efe-80ff-4db4ea889a5e > > Reason: Please check your firewall rules and network connection, then try again. Error Code: net::ERR_NETWORK_CHANGED. This is with `gpt-5-mini` and the message is different for each provider. Grok tells me it's because the network changed. Started happening since I enabled a Multi-WAN interface that combine all active network interfaces from different ISP/routers. I know it's not a standard interface/config but it's very useful (particularily in my case) as it helps to get a stable, reliable and redundant connexion. It's not urgent or anything but it's annoying to hit the retry button every time. Here is the script shell functions I use to set it up to help for reproduction: https://gist.github.com/wasertech/8acbdb9b12ac610cc9e04c8b5c4fafa1 Extension version: 0.30.3 VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.15.9-2-MANJARO Modes:

title: Add copilot setting to not kill terminals

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Please add a setting that allows me to configure copilot chat to NOT kill the terminal when I open a new chat session. I had several long debugging sessions where the coding agent and I ran various commands and then accidentally when clicking "new session" in chat because the agent had compacted and started to turn in circles I lost the whole terminal output with lots of important debugging output. I would recommend that the default shouldn't be to auto-kill terminals (how it used to until recently?) and have the auto-kill as opt-in setting. But at least please give me opt-out setting that allows me to keep terminals and only kill them myself when no longer needed. Thanks!

title: Bug: Some built-in tools in .chatmode.md files throw "Unexpected token" error
body: * **Copilot Chat Extension Version**: \[v0.30.3] * **VS Code Version**: \[1.103.2] * **OS Version**: \[Windows 11] * **Feature**: chatmode (`.chatmode.md`) * **Selected model**: \[e.g., GPT-4.1] * **Logs**: N/A --- ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create a new file under `.github/chatmodes/playwright-tester.chatmode.md`. 2. Add the following content: ```yaml --- description: "Testing mode for Playwright tests." tools: ["openSimpleBrowser", "fetch"] --- ``` 3. Save the file. --- ### Expected Behavior All built-in Copilot tools (e.g., `openSimpleBrowser`) should be accepted without errors inside the `tools` list. --- ### Actual Behavior VS Code shows a parsing error: ``` Unexpected token 'openSimpleBrowser' ``` Only a subset of tools (`fetch`, `findTestFiles`, `editFiles`, `runCommands`) are accepted. Adding others causes validation errors. --- ### Notes * Reproducible consistently. * Happens in `.chatmode.md` files only. * Might be a schema validation bug or incomplete tool support. ---

title: Frequent request failed on tools schema

title: fix: memory leak in InlayHints
body:
### Before

Scrolling up and down in an editor 197 times:

![shapes at 25-09-04 12 48 22](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8b004a33-e1cd-43ae-a6c7-0eeaf76875b9)


It seems that when scrolling the the inlay hints are queried and added to `sessionDisposables` making `sessionDisposables` grow by one each time.


### Change

The change uses a separate `disposableStore` so that each time the `RunOnceScheduler` runs, the previous `disposableStore` removed and disposed. 


In order to not manage the `cancelToken`, `disposableStore` and `mutableDisposable` individually, a new class `CancellationStore` has been added that combines them.

title: Support for Uploading and Analyzing More File Formats in Copilot Chat Agent (e.g., Excel, PDF)

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Type: Feature Request Currently, when trying to upload files such as Excel (.xlsx) into the Copilot Pro+ chat agent in Visual Studio Code, the system shows that the file type is not supported. However, since the chat agent is powered by AI, it should be able to analyze, read, and reason over a wide variety of file formats. This is especially important for workflows where developers want to quickly generate code, perform data analysis, or extract structured information from files directly inside VS Code. Why this matters: Many real-world use cases involve working with data stored in Excel or CSV files. Developers also often need to reference or extract content from PDFs, Word documents, and other formats. Limiting supported file types reduces the usefulness of Copilot as an AI assistant and forces users to rely on external tools. Suggested improvement: Expand file upload and analysis support in Copilot Pro+ chat agent to include common formats such as Excel, CSV, PDF, DOCX, and potentially others. Allow developers to directly query these files in chat for code generation, data analysis, and documentation purposes. This would make Copilot significantly more versatile and aligned with how developers actually work with files day-to-day. title: Add --transient option to help output troubleshooting section
body:
The `--transient` command line option was not appearing in the help output, making it difficult for users to discover this useful debugging feature.

## Problem

The `--transient` option creates temporary directories for user data and extensions, which is helpful for testing and debugging without affecting the user's normal VS Code configuration. However, this option was missing from the help output because it lacked the necessary metadata required by the help generation system.

## Root Cause

The help generation function `buildHelpMessage()` only includes options in the output if they have both a `description` and a `cat` (category) property:

```typescript
else if (o.description && o.cat) {
    // Option is included in help
}
```

The `transient` option was defined as:
```typescript
'transient': { type: 'boolean' },
```

Without the required `cat` and `description` properties, it was excluded from help output.

## Solution

Added the missing metadata to categorize the option under "Troubleshooting" and provide a clear description:

```typescript
'transient': { type: 'boolean', cat: 't', description: localize('transient', "Use temporary directories for user data and extensions. Changes will not persist after restart.") },
```

- `cat: 't'` places it in the "Troubleshooting" section alongside other debugging options
- `description` explains what the option does and its temporary nature
- Follows VS Code's existing localization patterns

## Testing

Run `code --help` to verify the `--transient` option now appears under the "Troubleshooting" section. The functionality of the option itself remains unchanged.
